revision.text:
<!-- Missing image removed: [[Image:AgentsOfGamingLogo.gif|frame|right]] --> '''Agents of Gaming''' was a [[game design]] [[studio]] that started out in January 1992 by Bruce Graw. The company's original purpose was to run [[Galactic Conquest (play-by-mail game)|Galactic Conquest]], the [[play-by-mail game]] which became [[Star Fleet Warlord]]. Galactic Conquest had originally been run as a hobby (first created in late 1989), but proved its worth in the first eight games as a legitimate play-by-mail game. The public debut came at Gen Con/Origins 1992, followed shortly by a deal to make it an official Star Fleet Universe product (a change of the name to the Star Fleet Warlord).
[[Continental Conquest]] (then called Conquest of America) was written in 1992 and also started its first game at [[Gen Con/Origins]]. The European map was added in mid-1993 and the revision to the current rules (including the Oceania map) was completed in mid-1995.
The concept for [[Babylon 5 Wars]] was created by [[Robert N. Glass|Robert Glass]] in April 1996 and pitched to Agents of Gaming, and was nearly dismissed as an impossible prospect. Robert persisted, calling [[Warner Brothers]], and was able to secure the license with the help of Agents of Gaming credentials. [[Kelly Lofgren]] was brought on board shortly thereafter. The basic game system took nearly a year to write, refine and playtest before it was finished in April 1997.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/19970702074746/http://www.agentsofgaming.com/bruce.htm Agents of Gaming Background]</ref>
They also created several tabletop [[wargaming]] products before their closing on November 1, 2002. It collapsed shortly after Warner Brothers pulled their [[Babylon 5]] license, citing concerns that the license was not being grown. <ref>[http://worldsofjms.com/usenet/post/020929a.htm J. Michael Straczynski describing the collapse]</ref>
Their notable games include: * ''[[Babylon 5 Wars]]'' ([[Origins Award]] nominee) * ''[[Babylon 5: Fleet Action]]''
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.agentsofgaming.com/ Official website]

{{notability|corp|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox dot-com company | name = Aniboom | logo = | caption = AniboomLogo | url = [https://www.facebook.com/Aniboom Aniboom Facebook page] | alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 249,372 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/aniboom.com |title= Aniboom.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }} | registration = Optional
(required to upload, rate, and comment on videos) | company_type = [[Limited liability company]] | foundation = January 2006 | location_city = [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]]
[[San Francisco]], [[California]] | key_people = Uri Shinar, Founder & CEO | launch_date = {{start date|2006|11|24}} | current_status = Defunct | website_type = Animation studio }} '''Aniboom''' was an online [[animation]] studio, which distributed independent animated short films and occasionally co-produced them.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/01/11/anibooms-animation-studio-ambitions/|author=Roi Carthy|title=AniBoom's Animation-Studio Ambitions|work=[[TechCrunch]]|date=January 11, 2008|accessdate=August 17, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-aniboom-youtube-idUSN1922595220070820|author=Michele Gershberg|title=Animation site Animboom launches YouTube channel|work=[[Reuters]]|date=August 20, 2007|accessdate=August 17, 2016}} It was founded in 2006 by former Israeli television executive Uri Shinar.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/16/movies/16mass.html|title=An Animated Film Is Created Through Internet Consensus|last=Barnes|first=Brooks|date=2009-07-16|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-08-16}} Within three years, over 13,000 clips were released through the studio, at which point ''[[The New York Times]]'' described Aniboom's business structure as perhaps the largest example of [[crowdsourcing]] in the entertainment industry. The studio's website went live in late September, 2006. Its official launch was not announced however, until November 24 of that year.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2006/11/23/animated-short-films-on-aniboom/|author=Michael Arrington|title=Animated Short Films on AniBoom|work=TechCrunch|date=November 23, 2006|accessdate=August 17, 2016}} The launch was accompanied by a contest, running through January 30 of the following year, in which the creators of the website's most highly rated films up to that point received monetary prizes.{{cite web|url=http://www.aniboom.com/Pages/Application/Competitions/CategoricalCompetitionAnimCol.aspx|author=aniBoom staff|title=aniBoom Awards 2006|work=AniBoom|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061210122247/http://www.aniboom.com/Pages/Application/Competitions/CategoricalCompetitionAnimCol.aspx|archivedate=December 10, 2006}} Over the following years, similar contests were held,{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2007/10/10/aniboom-gets-its-own-channel-on-joost/|author=Erick Schonfeld|title=AniBoom Gets Its Own Channel on Joost|work=TechCrunch|date=October 10, 2007|accessdate=August 17, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.awn.com/news/third-annual-aniboom-awards-open-submissions|author=Annemarie Moody|title=Third Annual Aniboom Awards Open For Submissions|work=[[Animation World Network]]|date=September 18, 2008|accessdate=August 17, 2016}} and Aniboom expanded its online presence to include channels on [[Joost]] and [[YouTube]]. In 2008, the studio raised $10 million in investor funding.{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/06/26/aniboom-believed-to-raise-10-million-from-dfj/|title=Aniboom Believed to Raise $10 Million from DFJ|author=Erick Schonfeld|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2016-08-16}} The Aniboom short "Live Music" was picked up by Sony for theatrical distribution in 2009, as an opener for [[Planet 51]]. The same year, Aniboom ran a competition in partnership with the [[Fox Broadcasting Company]] – the best holiday themed short film, as chosen by Fox executives, would win $15,000 and the possibility of a development deal.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2009/05/18/fox-television-tries-to-crowdsource-cartoons-through-aniboom/|author=Erick Schonfeld|title=Fox Television Tries To Crowdsource Cartoons Through Aniboom|work=TechCrunch|date=May 18, 2009|accessdate=August 17, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/tv/fox-aniboom-seek-holiday-special-ideas/|author=Tom McLean|title=Fox, Aniboom Seek Holiday Special Ideas|work=[[Animation Magazine]]|date=May 18, 2009|accessdate=August 17, 2016}} The contest was won by Jay Malone for the short film ''Santa Intervention''.{{cite web|url=http://www.aniboom.com/competition/fox|author=aniBoom staff|title=FOX-Aniboom Holiday Animation Challenge: Grand Prize Winner – Jay Malone|work=aniBoom|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100111025421/http://www.aniboom.com/competition/fox#sort:Shuffled;page:0;filter:|archivedate=January 11, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.awn.com/news/fox-award-development-deal-winner-fox-aniboom-holiday-animation-challenge|author=Matt Kapko|title=Fox to Award Development Deal to Winner of Fox-Aniboom Holiday Animation Challenge|work=Animation World Network|date=November 23, 2009|accessdate=August 17, 2016}} As of 2016 the official website has closed and the official YouTube channel has been terminated.{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.facebook.com/Aniboom Aniboom Facebook Page] * [http://www.dailymotion.com/aniboom Aniboom Dailymotion Page] [[Category:Film websites]] [[Category:Websites about animation]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2006]] [[Category:Video hosting]] [[Category:Entertainment websites]] [[Category:Defunct websites]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2012}} An '''Australian Government Film''' is an Australian film that has been funded by the Australian government at either a state or federal level. This type of film is distinct from an [[Australian independent film]] which has had no up-front government investment.
Most Australian films are funded by one or more of the state or federal film funding bodies such as Screen Australia, The NSW Film and Television Office, Film Victoria, ScreenWest, and The South Australian Film Corp.
(NB - may contain some independent films - the list is not yet completely researched)
'''Notable Australian Government Films of the 1940s-1950s:''' *''[[Kokoda Front Line!]]'' (1942) - First Australian film to win an Oscar, for Best Documentary Feature in 1942 *''[[Conquest of The Rivers]]'' (1958) - AFI winner for Best Film (recruitment film for the Snowy Hydro scheme)
'''Notable Australian Government Films of the 1960s:''' *''[[The Dancing Class]]'' (1964) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[I The Aboriginal]]'' (1964) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[The Legend of Damien Parer]]'' (1965) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Stronger Since The War]]'' (1965) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Concerto for Orchestra (film)|Concerto for Orchestra]]'' (1966) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Cardin in Australia]]'' (1967) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[The Change at Groote]]'' (1968) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[The Talgai Skull]]'' (1968) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Jack and Jill: A Postscript]]'' (1969) - AFI winner for Best Film
'''Notable Australian Government Films of the 1970s:''' *''[[Three To Go: Michael]]'' (1970) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Homesdale]]'' (1971) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Marco Polo Junior Versus the Red Dragon|Marco Polo Jr. Versus the Red Dragon]]'' (1972) - Australia's first animated feature film. *''[[Sunday Too Far Away]]'' (1975) - AFI winner for Best Film, acclaimed for its realism in character portrayal *''[[Picnic at Hanging Rock (film)|Picnic at Hanging Rock]]'' (1975) - One of the first Australian films to reach an International audience, based on a book of the same title *''[[The Devil's Playground (1976 film)|The Devil's Playground]]'' (1976) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith]]'' (1976) - A multi-award winning film *''[[Storm Boy (1976 film)|Storm Boy]]'' (1977) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[The Getting of Wisdom]]'' (1977) - Nominated for 5 AFI Awards and winner of Best Adapted Screenplay *''[[Newsfront]]'' (1978) - Winner of 8 AFI awards including Best Film and Best Actor: Bill Hunter. *''[[Mouth to Mouth (1978 film)|Mouth to Mouth]]'' (1978) - AFI Nominee Kim Krejus *''[[My Brilliant Career (film)|My Brilliant Career]]'' (1979) - AFI winner for Best Film
==1980s==
'''Notable Australian Government Films of the 1980s:''' *''[[Breaker Morant (film)|'Breaker' Morant]]'' (1980) - Nominated for an Oscar (for Best Screenplay), AFI winner for Best Film *''Running On Empty (1982) - Classic Australian Drag Racing Movie. *''[[Careful, He Might Hear You]]'' (1983) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Annie's Coming Out]]'' (1984) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Bliss (1985 film)|Bliss]]'' (1985) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Malcolm (film)|Malcolm]]'' (1986) - AFI winner for Best Film. One of the first films starring [[Colin Friels]]. *[[The Lighthorsemen (film)|''The Lighthorsemen'' (film)]], a 1987 feature film about an Australian Light Horse unit *''[[The Year My Voice Broke]]'' (1987) - Often cited by film critics as the best Australian film in the past 25 years., AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Dogs in Space]]'' (1987) - A cult film set in the post-punk "little band scene" in Melbourne in 1979. *''[[Evil Angels (film)|Evil Angels]]'' (''A Cry in the Dark'')<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094924/releaseinfo#akas|title=A Cry in the Dark (1988) - Release dates |publisher= IMDb.com|accessdate=2012-06-15}}</ref> (1989) - AFI winner for Best Film and [[Meryl Streep]] Best Actress Oscar Nominee *''[[Houseboat Horror]]'' (1989) - featuring [[Alan Dale]] from ''[[Neighbours]]''
==1990s==
The 1990s saw the release of the cult classics ''[[The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert]]'' in 1994 and ''[[The Castle (1997 Australian film)|The Castle]]'' in 1997. ''[[Strictly Ballroom]]'' was also a successful and influential release.
'''Notable Australian Government Films of the 1990s:''' *''[[Flirting (film)|Flirting]]'' (1990) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Proof (1991 film)|Proof]]'' (1991) - AFI winner for Best Film, one of the first major films starring [[Russell Crowe]] and [[Hugo Weaving]]. *''[[Romper Stomper]]'' (1992) - A multi-award winning film, one of the first major films starring [[Russell Crowe]]. *''[[Strictly Ballroom]]'' (1992) - Nominated for Golden Globe, with additional 16 wins and 11 further nominations. AFI winner for Best Film *''[[The Piano]]''(1993) - New Zealand co-production, won 3 Oscars and received a further 5 nominations. AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Bad Boy Bubby]]'' (1994) - Won four AFI awards; Best Director (Rolf de Heer), Best Actor in a Leading Role (Nicholas Hope), Best Original Screenplay and Best Editing. *''[[Muriel's Wedding]]'' (1994) - AFI winner for Best Film with worldwide success, one of the first films introducing [[Toni Collette]] and [[Rachel Griffiths]] *''[[The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert]]'' (1994) - A cult classic, now a performing [[Priscilla: Queen of the Desert (The Musical)|musical production]]. The first large-scale appearance of [[Guy Pearce]] and [[Hugo Weaving]]. *''[[Angel Baby (1995 film)|Angel Baby]]'' (1995) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Babe (film)|Babe]]'' (1995) - Won an Oscar, for Best Achievement in Visual Effects and nominated a further six *''[[Così (film)|Così]]'' - AFI winner for best screenplay; 2 other nominations. Ensemble piece starring Barry Otto, Toni Colette, David Wenham and Ben Mendlesohn. *''[[Shine (film)|Shine]]'' (1996) - AFI winner for Best Film, Geoffrey Rush won Best Actor Oscar *''[[Idiot Box (film)|Idiot Box]]'' (1996) - Ben Mendelsohn & Jeremy Sims star *''[[Hotel de Love]]'' (1996) - Aden Young, Saffron Burrows *''[[Love and Other Catastrophes]]'' (1996) - nominated for 5 AFI awards *''[[Dating the Enemy]]'' (1996) - Guy Pearce and Claudia Karvan star *''[[Kiss or Kill (1997 film)|Kiss Or Kill]]'' (1997) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Doing Time for Patsy Cline]]'' (1997) - 10 AFI nominations winner of 4 (inc. Best Actor) *''[[Blackrock (film)]]'' (1997) - Nominated for 5 AFI awards and the movie debut of [[Heath Ledger]] *''[[Crackers (1998 film)|Crackers]]'' (1998) *''[[The Boys (1998 film)]]'' (1998) - Nominated for 13 AFI awards, winner of 5, including Best Director *''[[The Interview (1998 film)|The Interview]]'' (1998) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Paperback Hero (1999 film)|Paperback Hero]]'' (1998) - Hugh Jackman, Claudia Karvan *''[[Two Hands (1999 film)|Two Hands]]'' (1999) - AFI winner for Best Film
==2000s==
2000s in the history of Australian film has had some mixed successful films from ''[[Moulin Rouge!]]'' revitalizing the musical film genre, award winning short film ''[[Harvie Krumpet]]'', and box office success ''[[Happy Feet]]''.
'''Notable Australian Government Films of the 2000s:''' *''[[The Dish]]'' (2000) - An internationally successful film which presents a somewhat fictionalised account of the Parkes Observatory's role in the Apollo 11 moon landing. *''[[Bootmen]]'' (2000) - A multi-award winning film, one of the first films starring [[Sam Worthington]] and [[Adam Garcia]] *''[[Better Than Sex (film)|Better Than Sex]]'' (2000) - David Wenham, Susie Porter *''[[Chopper (film)|Chopper]]'' (2000) - A multi-award winning influential film based on the character of [[Mark Brandon Read|Mark Brandon "Chopper" Read]] *''[[Looking for Alibrandi (film)|Looking for Alibrandi]]'' (2000) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[The Bank (2001 film)|The Bank]]'' (2001) - Hi-Tech Thriller capilalising on strong anti-bank sentiment. *''[[Silent Partner (2001 film)|Silent Partner]]'' (2001) - A low budget - almost no-budget - film that offers an excellent and sensitive study about mateship between two losers. *''[[Lantana (film)|Lantana]]'' (2001) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Moulin Rouge!]]'' (2001) - Widely credited with revitalising the musical genre and has won 7 major awards and a further 10 nominations. *''[[The Man Who Sued God]]'' (2001) - AFI nomination for Best Original Screenplay (Don Watson), starring [[Billy Connolly]], Judy Davis and Colin Friels. *''[[One Night the Moon]]'' (2001) - AFI winner and New York International Independent Film & Video Festival Genre award winner. A musical (winner, Screen Music Awards, Australia) based on the true story of a young girl who went missing in the Australian outback in 1932. *''[[WillFull]]'' (2001) - The willful ghost of a parent returns. *''[[The Tracker]]'' (2002) - AFI winner for Best Actor: David Gulpilil *''[[Rabbit-Proof Fence (film)|Rabbit-Proof Fence]]'' (2002) - AFI winner for Best Film. Based on the book ''[[Follow the Rabbit-Proof Fence]]'' and stirred debate over its historical accuracy. *''[[Dirty Deeds (2002 film)|Dirty Deeds]]'' (2002) - 3 wins and 9 nominations. *''[[The Hard Word]]'' (2002) - 5 wins and 8 nominations. *''[[Swimming Upstream]]'' (2002) - Geoffrey Rush, Judy Davis, Jesse Spencer, Tim Draxl *''[[Harvie Krumpet]]'' (2003) - Won Oscar, for Best Short Film (Animated) *''[[Gettin' Square]]'' (2003) - AFI winner for Best Film AFI winner for Best Actor: [[David Wenham]] *''[[Take Away]]'' (2003) *''[[Japanese Story]]'' (2003) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Undead (film)|Undead]]'' (2003) *''[[On The Beach (2004 film)|On The Beach]]'' (2004) - 2 AFI Nominations (Armand Assante, Rachel Ward, Bryan Brown, Jaqueline McKenzie, Grant Bowler, Steve Bastoni) *''[[Love's Brother]]'' (2004) *''[[Strange Bedfellows (2004 film)|Strange Bedfellows]]'' (2004) *''[[Somersault (film)|Somersault]]'' (2004) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[Wolf Creek (film)|Wolf Creek]]'' (2005) - Seven AFI Nominations - including Best Director (John Jarratt, Nathan Philips) *''[[Look Both Ways]]'' (2005) - AFI winner for Best Film *''[[The Proposition (2005 film)|The Proposition]]'' (2005) *''[[The Illustrated Family Doctor]]'' (2005) - Samuel Johnson, Colin Friels, Jessica Napier, Sacha Horler *''[[Three Dollars]]'' (2005) - Based on the novel by Elliot Perlman and starring David Wenham and Frances O'Connor. *''[[Little Fish (film)|Little Fish]]'' (2005) - Cate Blanchett, Hugo Weaving and Noni Hazlehurst all won AFI awards for this film set in Sydney. *''[[Opal Dream|Opal Dream (film)]]'' (2006) - Vince Colosimo, Jacqueline McKenzie, Christian Byers, Sapphire Boyce *''[[Ten Canoes]]'' (2006) - First film made with entirely native Australian Aboriginal spoken languages. AFI winner for Best Film. *''[[Candy (2006 film)|Candy]]'' (2006) - Abbie Cornish, Heath Ledger and Geoffrey Rush in a film about love and how drugs affect your life. *''[[Jindabyne (film)|Jindabyne]]'' (2006) - Laura Linney & Gabriel Byrne in a film set in Jindabyne. *''[[Happy Feet]]'' (2006) - The most expensive Australian film made, was the first Australian film to win an Oscar for Best animated feature film. *''[[Who Killed Dr Bogle and Mrs Chandler?]]'' (2006) - Answer to [[Bogle–Chandler case|Australia's largest murder mystery]] and winner of Most Outstanding Documentary in the 2007 Logies. *''[[Last Train to Freo]]'' (2006) *''[[Kokoda (film)]]'' (2006) *''[[Romulus, My Father (film)|Romulus, My Father]]'' (2007) - [[Australian Film Institute Award for Best Film]] winner starring [[Eric Bana]]. *''[[Lucky Miles]]'' (2007) *''[[Clubland (2007 film)|Clubland]]'' (2007) *''[[Noise (2007 Australian film)|Noise]]'' (2007) *''[[Rogue (film)|Rogue]]'' (2007) *''[[December Boys]]'' (2007) - Based on the book, starring [[Daniel Radcliffe]]. *''[[Newcastle (film)|Newcastle]]'' (2008) Australian surfing drama film set in the New South Wales city of Newcastle. *''[[The Square (2008 film)|The Square]]'' (2008) - Nominated for 7 AFI awards including Best Picture, Best Director and Best Actor. Winner 2008 IF Awards - Best Sound. *''[[The Black Balloon (film)|The Black Balloon]]'' (2008) - Featuring Toni Collette, Gemma Ward. *''[[Unfinished Sky]]'' (2008) *''[[Among Dead Men]]'' (2008) - Winner 2008 Action on Film Festival's Best Fight Choreography *''[[Australia (2008 film)|Australia]]'' (2008) - a Baz Luhrmann Film starring Nicole Kidman, Hugh Jackman. *''[[Balibo (2009 film)|Balibo]]'' (2009) *''[[Samson and Delilah (2009 film)|Samson and Delilah]]'' (2009) - Cannes Camera D'or winner. *''[[Beautiful Kate]]'' (2009) *''[[Mary and Max]]'' (2009) *''[[Charlie & Boots]]'' (2009) *''[[Offside (2009 film)|Offside]]'' (2009)
==2010s==
*''[[Bran Nue Dae (film)|Bran Nue Dae]]'' (2010) *''[[Animal Kingdom (film)|Animal Kingdom]]'' (2010) *''[[Tomorrow, When the War Began (film)|Tomorrow, When the War Began]]'' (2010) *''[[Daybreakers]]'' (2010) - starring [[Ethan Hawke]], Sam Neill, [[Willem Dafoe]], Isabel Lucas and Vince Colosimo *''[[I Love You Too (2010 film)|I Love You Too]]'' (2010) - written by Peter Helliar, starring Peter Helliar, Yvonne Strahovski, Peter Dinklage and Brendan Cowell *''[[Red Hill (film)|Red Hill]]'' (2010) *''[[Wog Boy 2: Kings of Mykonos]]'' (2010) *''[[The Reef (2010 film)|The Reef]]'' (2010) *''[[Sanctum (film)|Sanctum]]'' (2011) Employed Executive Producer [[James Cameron]] for 3D effects. One of the most successful Australian films at the box office. *''[[Snowtown (film)|Snowtown]]'' (2011) *''[[Red Dog (film)|Red Dog]]'' (2011) *''[[Little Johnny: The Movie]]'' (2011) *''[[Any Questions for Ben? (film)|Any Questions for Ben?]]'' (2012)

{{EngvarB|date=September 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} The '''Australian Sport Awards''' originally called the Sport Australia Awards were established by the [[Confederation of Australian Sport]] in 1980.{{cite book|title=Oxford Companion to Australian Sport|date=1994|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Melbourne|pages=108–109|edition=2nd}} From 1980 to 1996, the awards were limited to seven categories. In 1993, there was a merger of the Sport Australia Awards and the [[ABC Sports Award of the Year]].{{cite journal|title=Inaugural ABC Sport Awards|journal=Sport Report|date=1993|volume=13|issue=4|pages=3}} [[Dawn Fraser]] Award was introduced in 2000 to reflect the achievements and standing of Dawn Fraser in Australia and on the international sporting stage.{{cite web|title=Dawn Fraser Award|url=http://www.sportforall.com.au/?page_id=105|website=Confederation of Australian Sport|accessdate=8 February 2015}} ==Major athlete awards== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{Infobox video game | title = Bionic Commando | image = Bionic Commando.jpg | developer = [[Grin (company)|Grin]] | publisher = [[Capcom]] | director = Ulf Andersson | producer = Ben Judd | designer = | programmer = | artist = | writer = | composer = | series = ''[[Bionic Commando]]'' | engine = [[Diesel game engine|Diesel engine]] | platforms = [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Microsoft Windows]] | released = '''PlayStation 3''' & '''Xbox 360'''
{{Video game release|NA|May 19, 2009|AU|May 21, 2009|EU|May 22, 2009|JP|June 25, 2009}}'''Microsoft Windows'''
{{Video game release|NA|July 28, 2009|JP|October 29, 2009|EU|October 30, 2009|AU|2009}} | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]]{{cite web |url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/21670/Bionic_Commando/ |title=Bionic Commando |website=[[Steam (software)|Steam]] |publisher=[[Valve Corporation]]}}
[[Third person shooter]]{{cite web | url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/bionic-commando__ |title=Bionic Commando for PlayStation 3 (2009) |website=[[MobyGames]] |publisher=Blue Flame Labs}} | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} {{nihongo|'''Bionic Commando'''|バイオニックコマンドー|Baionikkukomandō|lead=yes}} is a 2009 [[action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[video game]], part of the ''[[Bionic Commando (arcade)|Bionic Commando]]'' series. The game was developed and published by Capcom in collaboration with Swedish developer [[Grin (company)|Grin]]. The game is a sequel to the 1988 NES game ''[[Bionic Commando (Nintendo Entertainment System)|Bionic Commando]]'', with certain storyline elements taken from its 2008 [[Video game remake|remake]] ''[[Bionic Commando Rearmed]]''. The game runs on Grin's own 'Diesel' engine. ==Gameplay== {{Expand section|date=December 2009}} ''Bionic Commando'' is an action-adventure game, in which the player controls player-character [[Rad Spencer|Nathan Spencer]]. The game uses several mechanics (primarily radiation) which act as barriers. These barriers are used to keep the players within the confines of the linear level design. Nathan Spencer is able to target enemies while hanging, climbing a building or even in mid-swing, while using an implement called the Bionic Arm which can also be used to [[Melee|attack enemies at close range]]. The bionic arm can be used to grab and launch objects such as boulders and cars at enemies. In addition, he is equipped with boots that enable him to survive extremely long falls. Spencer is equipped with Tungsten gun, which is shot quickly but does minimum damage to the enemies, and Prototype gun, which fires fast and does maximum damage. ==Synopsis== [[Image:Bionic Commando Screen.jpg|thumb|left|The main character of the game, Nathan Spencer]] The events of the game take place ten years after the original game.{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/previews/bionic-commando_6 |title=Bionic Commando (Preview) |last=Hayward |first=Andrew |date=October 19, 2007 |website=[[1UP.com]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307125155/http://www.1up.com/previews/bionic-commando_6 |archivedate=March 7, 2016 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} The game follows Major Nathan "RAD" Spencer ([[Voice acting|voiced]] by [[Faith No More]] singer [[Mike Patton]]),{{cite web |url=http://360.advancedmn.com/article.php?artid=11531 |title=Faith No More's Mike Patton to Voice Bionic Commando |date=October 18, 2007}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}} a government operative working in the fictional Ascension City and an Operative named Joseph Gibson aka "Super Joe" (voiced by [[Steven Blum]]) for the Tactical Arms and Security Committee (T.A.S.C) that trains bionic operatives like Spencer. After he is betrayed by his own government and falsely imprisoned, the Great Bionic Purge begins. Before his execution, an experimental weapon detonates in Ascension City, unleashing an earthquake along with a radioactive shock wave that leaves the city destroyed and wiping out its populace. The terrorist force known as the "BioReign" claims responsibility, threatening invasion.{{cite web |url=http://www.cheatcc.com/ccc_newsserver/Article.aspx?PostID=374174 |title=Capcom Revitalizes Bionic Commando |website=Cheat Code Central |date=October 16, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017000114/http://www.cheatcc.com/ccc_newsserver/Article.aspx?PostID=374174 |archivedate=October 17, 2007 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} Spencer is freed to redeem his name along with the T.A.S.C's and is reunited with the bionic arm of which he was stripped.{{cite web |url=http://www.bioniccommando.com/en/pages/NG_Key_figures/id:1#content |title=Characters |website=Bionic Commando |publisher=[[Capcom]]}} During flashbacks the player learns that two years prior Spencer and his bionic partner Lt. Jayne Magdalene failed to eliminate two rogue bionics who had allegedly murdered a handful of people. Spencer resolved to help the two bionics escape when he and his partner discovered that the FSA were actively rounding up and forcibly rehabilitating bionics; something that both Spencer and Magdalene were themselves. Soon after the two rogue bionics and a wounded Lt. Magdalene escaped, Spencer was arrested by the FSA and sentenced to be executed for his treason. Returning to the present, Gibson releases Spencer on the condition that he assist the FSA against the threat to Ascension City. When given this ultimatum in exchange for his freedom, Spencer initially turns it down, but Gibson tells him he has knowledge of Spencer's missing wife. As Spencer progresses through Ascension City, he discovers information on Project Vulture, a super weapon being sought after by the terrorists. Spencer is ordered to retrieve the item before the Bio-Reign terrorists can. After finally gaining access to the item, he is betrayed by Joe who reveals himself as the leader of Bio-Reign. Joe has also enlisted the help of Gottfried Groeder, a character introduced in ''[[Bionic Commando Rearmed]]''. Joe then reveals that Spencer's wife never left, and alludes to the concept that she is actually part of Spencer's bionic arm. According to Super Joe, in order for bionics to work perfectly, they have to sync with their host on both an emotional and physical level. In this case, Spencer's wife was the perfect candidate. After this revelation, Spencer hastens his pursuit after Joe who activates Project Vulture before Spencer reaches him. Magdalene tries to stall Super Joe, now in a Bio-Mech suit, but she is killed while Spencer is forced to helplessly watch. In a fierce mid-air battle, Spencer kills Joe and ultimately stops Project Vulture. He falls back into the hole of The Vault from which he, Joe and the vultures had ascended earlier. In the epilogue a brief conversation in Morse code is shown between the sniper (Thomas Clarke) who'd been following Spencer, and an unknown party. The first message reports that the Vault had been occupied and the Vulture Sentry System had been "disabled" before requesting further instructions. While the coded reply was not decrypted from Morse code for the audience (encrypted message is in German once decrypted), it apparently reveals the following declaration in response: "Execution of Phase Two Prepared. Activate Project Albatros [sic]." ==Development== A [[comic book]] tie-in was written by [[Andy Diggle]], with [[Colin Wilson (comics)|Colin Wilson]] providing the art.{{cite web |url=http://www.bioniccommando.com/en/comics/ |title=Bionic Commando Comics |website=Bionic Commando |publisher=Capcom |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100113104729/http://www.bioniccommando.com/en/comics/ |archivedate=January 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=May 12, 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.newsarama.com/465-diggle-bringing-bionic-commando-to-webcomics.html |title=Diggle: Bringing Bionic Commando to Webcomics |last=Kean |first=Benjamin Ong Pang |date=July 18, 2008 |website=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} In the weeks leading up to the title's release, every Wednesday a new page was posted on the game's website. These single pages were collected in a thirty-five page comic, which was offered as a bonus for pre-ordering the title. After the game's release, a monthly comic was published by Devil's Due Publishing. [[Heather Mills]] was approached to help work on the game due to her work with amputees, but could not reach a compensation agreement with the developers.{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/bizarre/article2440331.ece |title=Greedy Mucca’s out of lucka |newspaper=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] |publisher=[[News UK]] |date=May 21, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090522103413/http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/bizarre/article2440331.ece |archivedate=May 22, 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} Players can also use a code found in ''[[Bionic Commando: Rearmed]]'' to unlock a skin of "RAD" Spencer from the original game with short red hair, green blazer and converse like shoes. A similar unlock, the 'Prototype Weapon,' was also available via BCR. Capcom's [[Keiji Inafune]] described the working relationship with Grin as "messed up", a situation which had arisen in previous instances of collaborations between Japanese and western developers.{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2011/09/17/inafune-messed-up-working-relationship-led-to-bionic-commando/ |title=Inafune: 'Messed up' working relationship led to Bionic Commando's Wifearm |last=Gilbert |first=Ben |date=September 17, 2011 |website=[[Engadget]] ([[Joystiq]]) |publisher=[[Oath Inc.]] |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} Similarly Capcom president Haruhiro Tsujimoto stated: "Our experience with Bionic Commando has demonstrated the difficulty of outsourcing the development of new title to overseas companies".{{Cite news|url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/capcom-done-with-western-devs|title=Capcom done with Western devs|work=Eurogamer.net|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en}} ===Audio=== The soundtrack for the game was generally well received. Kotaku described it as "suitably epic as well, with classic Bionic Commando music remixed into the sort of score you'd expect from a big-budget action flick."{{cite web |url=https://kotaku.com/5271086/bionic-commando-review-grabbing-hands-grab-all-they-can |title=Bionic Commando - Grabbing Hands Grab All They Can |last=Fahey |first=Mike |date=May 27, 2009 |website=Kotaku |publisher=Gawker Media |accessdate=July 28, 2009}} Also available is the single rock and roll remix, "The Bionic Jam", created by artist [[vertexguy]] (Chris Kline). This appeared as a bonus track in the first mission, playing on a radio sitting on top a desk.{{cite web |url=http://www.sumthingdigital.com/AlbumDetails.aspx?albumid=3722 |title=The Bionic Jam |website=[[Sumthing Distribution]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809075816/http://www.sumthingdigital.com/AlbumDetails.aspx?albumid=3722 |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} ==Limited edition== Gamers who pre-ordered ''Bionic Commando'' from GameCrazy had a chance of winning a limited number of '80s-style metal lunchboxes. In Australia, anyone who pre-ordered the game received a Nathan Spencer figure by [[National Entertainment Collectibles Association|NECA]]. ==Appearance in other media== [[Nathan "Rad" Spencer|Spencer]] appears as a playable character in the crossover fighting games ''[[Marvel vs. Capcom 3: Fate of Two Worlds]]'', ''[[Ultimate Marvel vs. Capcom 3]]'' and ''[[Marvel vs. Capcom: Infinite]]'', sporting his look from the 2009 game. [[Dameon Clarke]] provided his voice.{{cite web |url=https://kotaku.com/5659506/the-newest-marvel-vs-capcom-3-characters-are |title=The Newest Marvel Vs. Capcom 3 Characters Are... |last=McWhertor |first=Michael |date=October 8, 2010 |website=Kotaku |publisher=Gawker Media}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews |PC = true |PS3 = true |X360 = true |na = 2009 |page=82}} |PSM_PS3 = {{Rating|2.5|5}}{{cite magazine |title=Review: Bionic Commando |magazine=[[PlayStation: The Official Magazine]] |publisher=Future plc |issue=21 |date=July 2009 |page=74}} |rev1 = ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |rev1_X360 = 7/10{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/5342221/Bionic-Commando-review.html |title=Bionic Commando review (X360) |last=Hoggins |first=Tom |date=May 18, 2009 |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]] |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} |rev2 = ''[[The Guardian]]'' |rev2_PS3 = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2009/may/19/bionic-commando-ps3-xbox360 |title=Game Review: Bionic Commando for Xbox 360 and PS3 |last=Boxer |first=Steve |date=May 19, 2009 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} |rev2_X360 = {{Rating|3|5}} |MC_PC = 69/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/bionic-commando |title=Bionic Commando for PC Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=CBS Interactive}} |MC_PS3 = 71/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/bionic-commando |title=Bionic Commando for PlayStation 3 Reviews |website=Metacritic |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} |MC_X360 = 70/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/bionic-commando |title=Bionic Commando for Xbox 360 Reviews |website=Metacritic |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} }} ''Bionic Commando'' received "average" reviews on all platforms according to the [[Review aggregator|review aggregation]] website [[Metacritic]]. [[IGN]] praised the visuals and unpredictable storyline of the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 versions. [[GameSpot]] said of both console versions, "''Bionic Commando'' has some enjoyable moments, but consistent fun always seems just out of arm's reach." In Japan, ''[[Famitsu]]'' gave both console versions a favorable review, giving each a score of 34 out of 40.{{Cite web|url=https://www.famitsu.com/cominy/?m=pc&a=page_h_title&title_id=5254|title=バイオニック コマンドー [PS3] / ファミ通.com|website=www.famitsu.com|access-date=2018-07-23}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.famitsu.com/cominy/?m=pc&a=page_h_title&title_id=175|title=バイオニック コマンドー [Xbox 360] / ファミ通.com|website=www.famitsu.com|access-date=2018-07-23}} ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the PS3 version an A− and said, "As you squeeze off headshots and sail around the stunningly rendered destroyed city, the game's only hiccup is in forcing you to read fine-print-sized text about the game's optional mythology. But don't let a little reading stop you from enjoying what's essentially a playable action movie."{{cite web |url=https://games.avclub.com/bionic-commando-1798216578 |title=Bionic Commando (PS3) |last=Wolinsky |first=David |date=May 25, 2009 |website=[[The A.V. Club]] |publisher=[[The Onion]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122022254/http://www.avclub.com/articles/bionic-commando,28278/ |archivedate=January 22, 2010 |deadurl=no |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' gave the Xbox 360 version seven out of ten and said, "Irritations aside, there's rarely a dull moment and a delightfully ludicrous storyline with high-camp villains frames the action nicely. As such, ''Bionic Commando'' at its best is a macho, cheeseball 80s action movie that Arnie or Sly would have been proud of." ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave the PS3 and Xbox 360 versions three stars out of five and said that the game "looks good, but feels generally soulless and generic. Hardcore gamers will like the advanced difficulty level, but novices will find it infuriating. A damp squib of a revival." ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]'' gave the Xbox 360 version a score of six out of ten and said, "The overriding impression is of a game that's physically too big for its action."{{cite magazine |url=http://www.edge-online.com/magazine/review-bionic-commando |title=Review: Bionic Commando (X360) |author=Edge staff |magazine=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]] |publisher=Future plc |issue=202 |date=June 2009 |page=88 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524010134/http://www.edge-online.com/magazine/review-bionic-commando |archivedate=May 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=May 13, 2018}} However, ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' gave the Xbox 360 version a score of five stars out of ten, saying that its concepts "are strong, but the moment-to-moment action just doesn't deliver on the promise of how awesome it would be to have a grappling hook instead of a hand."{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2009/05/review-bionic-commando/ |title=Review: Bionic Commando a Swing and a Miss (X360) |last=Kohler |first=Chris |date=May 18, 2009 |website=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |accessdate=May 12, 2018}} ''Bionic Commando'' sold 27,000 units in the U.S., during its first month.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/bionic-commando-boom-blox-2-start-slow/1100-6211994/|title=Bionic Commando, Boom Blox 2 start slow|last=Staff|first=Gamespot|date=2009-06-15|website=GameSpot|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-22}} In comparison, ''[[Terminator Salvation (video game)|Terminator Salvation]]'', which received worse reviews from critics, sold 43,000 units in the same length of time. VideoGamer.com's James Orry noted that the game "could end up being Capcom's first major flop in the high definition era."{{cite web |url=https://www.videogamer.com/news/bionic_commando_sells_only_27k_in_the_us.html |title=Bionic Commando sells only 27k in the US |last=Orry |first=James |date=June 15, 2009 |website=VideoGamer.com |publisher=Resero Network |accessdate=June 15, 2009}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131117181443/http://www.bioniccommando.com/ ''Bionic Commando'' official website]* *[http://www.capcom.com/ Publisher Capcom's official website] *{{moby game|id=/bionic-commando__}} {{Bionic Commando}} {{Diesel engine games}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bionic Commando (2009 video game)}} [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:3D platform games]] [[Category:Action video games]] [[Category:Bionic Commando]] [[Category:Capcom games]] [[Category:Diesel (game engine) games]] [[Category:Games for Windows certified games]] [[Category:Grin (company) games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:Superhero video games]] [[Category:Terrorism in fiction]] [[Category:Third-person shooters]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games developed in Sweden]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=the 2010 video game ''[[Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter]]''}} {{Infobox video game | collapsible = | state = | italic title = | title = Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD | image = Carnivores Dinosaur Hunter HD cover.jpg | alt = | caption = | developer = Vogster Entertainment | publisher = Vogster Entertainment | series = ''[[Carnivores (series)|Carnivores]]'' | platforms = [[PlayStation 3]] | released = {{Video game release|US|September 10, 2013|EU|December 18, 2013}} | genre = [[First-person shooter]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} '''''Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD''''' is a 2013 [[first-person shooter]] video game developed and published by Vogster Entertainment. It is the sixth game in the [[Carnivores (series)|''Carnivores'' series]] of dinosaur-hunting games, serving as a sequel as well as a modern remake of the original game, ''[[Carnivores (video game)|Carnivores]]'' (1998). The game was released for the [[PlayStation 3]] (PS3) via the [[PlayStation Network]] (PSN). ''Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD'' received "Mixed or average reviews" according to [[Metacritic]].
==Gameplay== The game's premise is not told within the game itself. According to the [[PlayStation Network]] website, the player takes the role of a wealthy space-traveller in the future who hunts dinosaurs for sport on a distant planet similar to Earth.<ref name=HCG/><ref name=IGN/>
The game features three environments, including [[mesa]]s and forests, each with a daytime, dusk, and fog setting.<ref name=IGN/> The player is rewarded with gems and money after each hunt.<ref name=OPM/> The amount rewarded depends on how well the player did on the hunt. Gems and points are used respectively to purchase new weapons and unlock new environments.<ref name=IGN/><ref name=OPM/> The player has access to a multi-purpose hunting device known as Gadget,<ref name=OPM/><ref name=Blog2/> which features a map, and informs whether the player is being watched by a dinosaur or making too much noise.<ref name=PS/> The device can be updated to include features such as radar, using gems earned from the hunts.<ref name=IGN/> The game does not feature any music, but includes dinosaur roars,<ref name=PS/> as well as the sounds of unseen birds, frogs, and insects.<ref name=IGN/>
Dinosaurs include ''[[Ankylosaurus]]'', ''[[Ceratosaurus]]'', ''[[Parasaurolophus]]'', ''[[Stegosaurus]]'', ''[[Triceratops]]'', and ''[[Tyrannosaurus rex]]''.<ref name=Blog2/> The player has the ability to evacuate a hunt at any time. Whenever the player is killed by a dinosaur, the screen fades to blackness rather than depicting a death scene. The player starts out hunting only herbivorous dinosaurs.<ref name=IGN/> Killed dinosaurs are beamed up by the player's personal spaceship,<ref name=OPM/> and the player can purchase trophy versions of each killed dinosaur and display them in a trophy room.<ref name=HCG/> The game includes the "Observer Mode," which allows the player to explore a chosen environment and observe the dinosaurs rather than hunt them.<ref name=Blog3/> The player also has the option to tranquilize a dinosaur rather than kill it.<ref name=IGN/>
==Development and release== ''Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD'' was developed and published by Vogster Entertainment.<ref name=PS/> It is a modern remake of the original 1998 ''[[Carnivores (video game)|Carnivores]]'' video game,<ref name=Blog3/> as well as a sequel in the [[Carnivores (series)|''Carnivores'' series]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD announced for PlayStation 3 |url=http://carnivoreshd.com:80/content/news.html |website=Carnivores HD website |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130912095544/http://carnivoreshd.com/content/news.html# |archivedate=2013-09-12 |date=September 3, 2013 |dead-url=yes |access-date=2018-11-20 |df= }}</ref> In the United States, the game was released for the [[PlayStation 3]] via the PlayStation Network on September 10, 2013.<ref name=PS/><ref name=Blog>{{cite web |last=Gutierrez |first=Rey |title=The Drop: Week of September 9th 2013 New Releases |url=https://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/09/08/the-drop-week-of-september-9th-2013-new-releases/ |website=PlayStation Blog |accessdate=June 27, 2018 |date=September 8, 2013}}</ref> After the game's North American release, Vogster Entertainment gathered user feedback to make further improvements to the game prior to its European release,<ref name=Blog2>{{cite web |last=Kuryavchenko |first=Artem |title=Carnivores HD: Dinosaur Hunter stomps onto PS3 next week |url=https://blog.eu.playstation.com/2013/12/10/carnivores-hd-dinosaur-hunter-stomps-onto-ps3-next-week/ |website=PlayStation Blog |accessdate=June 27, 2018 |location=Europe|date=December 10, 2013}}</ref> which occurred on December 18, 2013, through the PlayStation Network.<ref name=Blog3>{{cite web |last=Kuryavchenko |first=Artem |title=Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD arrives on PS3 today |url=https://blog.eu.playstation.com/2013/12/18/carnivores-dinosaur-hunter-hd-arrives-on-ps3-today/ |website=PlayStation Blog |accessdate=June 27, 2018 |location=Europe|date=December 18, 2013}}</ref>
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | title = | subtitle = <!--Formatting--> | state = <!--plain/collapsible--> | align = <!--left/right/none/inherit--> <!-- Aggregators --> | MC = 50/100<ref name=MC/> <!-- Reviewers --> | IGN = 4/10<ref name=IGN/> | OPMUK = 6/10<ref name=OPM/> <!-- Custom Reviewers limit is set to 10--> | rev1 = ''[[Hardcore Gamer]]'' | rev1Score = 2.5/5<ref name=HCG/> | rev2 = ''[[Push Square]]'' | rev2Score = 6/10<ref name=PS/> <!-- Awards No limit --> | award1Pub = | award1 = | award2Pub = | award2 = }} ''Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD'' received "Mixed or average reviews" according to [[Metacritic]].<ref name=MC>{{cite web |title=Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/carnivores-hd-dinosaur-hunter |website=Metacritic |accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref> Reviewers particularly criticized the game for its [[Grinding (gaming)|grinding gameplay]].<ref name=HCG/><ref name=IGN/><ref name=OPM/><ref name=PS/>
David Meikleham of ''[[PlayStation Official Magazine – UK]]'' noted that the game had "a pretty out-there premise." Meikleham criticized the high amount of gems and points needed to purchase and unlock parts of the game, such as weapons and levels. However, he also wrote, "Slow-burning, often unspectacular, this PSN hunter nevertheless has a charming depth if you've got the patience to unearth it."<ref name=OPM>{{cite web |last=Meikleham |first=David |title=Carnivores HD: Dinosaur Hunter PS3 review – Tense lizard blaster goes bland before its time |url=http://www.officialplaystationmagazine.co.uk/review/carnivores-hd-dinosaur-hunter-ps3-review-tense-lizard-blaster-goes-bland-before-its-time/ |website= PlayStation Official Magazine – UK|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140124232504/http://www.officialplaystationmagazine.co.uk/review/carnivores-hd-dinosaur-hunter-ps3-review-tense-lizard-blaster-goes-bland-before-its-time/ |archivedate=January 24, 2014 |date=January 23, 2014}}</ref> Robert Ramsey of ''[[Push Square]]'' praised the scenery, but noted the "cheap and tacky" design of the game's menus. Ramsey also criticized the repetitive dinosaur roars and the lack of music.<ref name=PS>{{cite web |last=Ramsey|first=Robert |title=Review: Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD (PlayStation 3) |url=http://www.pushsquare.com/reviews/psn/carnivores_dinosaur_hunter_hd |website=Push Square |accessdate=June 27, 2018 |date=September 23, 2013}}</ref>
Kallie Plagge of [[IGN]] called the game "slow, aimless, bland, and not nearly as exciting as the name would have us believe." Plagge stated that despite the "''HD''" in its title, the game had "some truly awful" and outdated textures. Plagge praised the environmental exploration as the highlight of the game, but was critical of the rewards system. Plagge also criticized the ability to evacuate a hunt, stating that "removing any sense of danger or risk takes a lot of the fun out of playing." Additionally, Plagge criticized the lack of player death scenes, and stated that the game "fails to deliver in almost every way."<ref name=IGN>{{cite web |last=Plagge |first=Kallie |title=Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD Review |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/09/27/carnivores-dinosaur-hunter-hd-review |website=IGN |accessdate=June 27, 2018 |date=September 26, 2013}}</ref>
Lee Cooper of ''[[Hardcore Gamer]]'' praised the controls but criticized some of the graphics as being "poorly rendered," and stated that while "the dinosaurs look pretty cool, and the environments are expansive and littered with detail, the game is simply not fun." Cooper also criticized the lack of an in-game storyline, but concluded that the game was the "best arcade-style dinosaur hunting game" available for the PS3.<ref name=HCG>{{cite web |last=Cooper |first=Lee |title=Review: Carnivores: Dinosaur Hunter HD |url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2013/09/22/review-carnivores-dinosaur-hunter-hd/55563/ |website=Hardcore Gamer |accessdate=June 27, 2018 |date=September 22, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140219203042/http://carnivoreshd.com/home.html Official website] (archived)

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Chicano Batman | background = group_or_band | image = Chicano Batman.jpg | image_size = 300 | alt = | caption = Chicano Batman at Emo's Austin, TX in 2017 | alias = | origin = [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States | occupation = | instrument = | years_active = 2008<ref name="billboard20150203" />–present | label = [[ATO Records|ATO]] | website = {{URL|chicanobatman.com/}} | Genre = [[Soul music|Soul]], [[Tropical music|tropical]], [[Psychedelic music|psychedelic]] | Associated_acts = | Current_members = * Eduardo Arenas * Carlos Arévalo * Bardo Martinez * Gabriel Villa | Past_members= }}
'''Chicano Batman''' is a four-piece American band based in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[California]].<ref name="CB_bio" /><ref name="AltLatino_20140503" /><ref name="AltLatino_20141218" /><ref name="AltLatino_20150205" /> Formed in 2008, the band is composed of Eduardo Arenas (bass, guitar, vocals), Carlos Arévalo (guitars), Bardo Martinez (lead vocals, keyboards, guitar) and Gabriel Villa (drums). The group's sound draws from a mix of genres ranging from [[psychedelic soul]], [[funk]], [[Independent music|indie]], [[tropicalia]], and [[Rock music|rock]].<ref name="AltLatino_20170607" />
== Biography == Chicano Batman was formed in 2008.<ref name="billboard20150203" /> [[NPR]]'s ''[[Alt.Latino]]'' referred to the band's music as one of the show's and listener's favorites of 2014.<ref name="AltLatino_20140503" /><ref name="AltLatino_20141218" /> Chicano Batman provided support for select dates on the January–February leg of [[Jack White]]'s Lazaretto Tour 2015.<ref name="billboard20150203" /><ref name="AltLatino_20150205" /><ref name="WES_20150301" /> In April 2015, the band performed on Day 3 (April 12 & 19) for both weekends of the [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]].<ref name="billboard20150203" /><ref name="AltLatino_20150205" /><ref name="WES_20150301" /><ref name="dailybulletin20150412" /> In July 2015, Chicano Batman performed at [[Ruido Fest]].<ref name="AltLatino_20150723" /> As of 2017, the band has played at Bonnaroo (2016) and LouFest (2016), as well as both weekends of Coachella (2017), Sasquatch! Music Festival (2017), the Forecastle Festival (2017), FYF (2017), Beer X (2017).
Chicano Batman made their late night television debut on ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' in 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://remezcla.com/music/chicano-batman-conan-performance/|title=Chicano Batman Made Their Late-Night TV Debut on ‘Conan’|date=2017-05-04|work=Remezcla|access-date=2017-05-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
They star in a 2018 commercial for [[Johnnie Walker]] [[Scotch whiskey]], singing ''[[This Land is Your Land]]''.
=== Musical Influences ===
In interviews, guitarist Carlos Arévalo points to band members' bonding over 1960's Brazilian artists [[Caetano Veloso]] and [[Tropicália]] music.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nuvo.net/music/chicano-batman-s-liberating-sound/article_551e2a22-bb63-11e8-96ea-1b7dc5ecaf64.html|title=Chicano Batman’s Liberating Sound|last=Johnson|first=Seth|date=2018-09-18|website=NUVO|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-19}}</ref> The band's signature style can be attributed to their musical influences, [[The Beatles]] and Black soul musicians [[Curtis Mayfield]] and the [[The Delfonics|Delfonics]].<ref name=":0" /> {{Expand section|date=August 2015}}
== Discography == Source:<ref name="CB_music" />
=== Singles and EPs === * ''Joven Navegante'' (2012) * ''Magma'' (2013) * ''Black Lipstick'' (2015) * "Please Don't Leave Me" (2016) * "This Land Is Your Land" (2017)
=== Albums === * ''Chicano Batman'' (2010) * ''Cycles of Existential Rhyme'' (2014)<ref name="billboard20150203" /><ref name="AltLatino_20140503" /><ref name="AltLatino_20141218" /><ref name="AltLatino_20150205" /> * ''[[Freedom Is Free (Chicano Batman album)|Freedom Is Free]]'' (2017) <ref name="AltLatino_20170111" />
== Members == Source:<ref name="CB_bio" /><ref name="AltLatino_20170607" /> * Eduardo Arenas – bass guitar, vocals * Carlos Arévalo – guitar * Bardo Martinez – lead vocals, organ, guitar * Gabriel Villa – drums, percussion
Gabriel Villa is from [[Cali|Cali, Colombia]].

|title=Meet Chicano Batman: Jack White's Opening Act Talks 'Championing the Underdog' |date=3 February 2015 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|billboard.com]] |accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref> <ref September 2015}}</ref> <ref name="AltLatino_20140503">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/altlatino/2014/05/03/308954769/dancing-to-the-radio-alt-latinos-cinco-de-mayo-playlist |title=Dancing To The Radio: Alt.Latino's Cinco De Mayo Playlist |date=3 May 2014 |work=NPR.org([[Alt.Latino]]) |accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref> <ref name="AltLatino_20141218">{{cite Feast |date=23 July 2015 |work=NPR.org(Alt.Latino) |accessdate=1 August 2015}}</ref> <ref name="AltLatino_20170111">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/altlatino/2017/01/11/509141239/the-alt-latino-spring-2017-new-music-preview |title=The Alt.Latino Spring 2017 New Music Preview |date=11 Jan 2017 |work=NPR.org(Alt.Latino) |accessdate=15 Jan 2017}}</ref> <ref name="AltLatino_20170607">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/altlatino/2017/06/07/531671438/guest-dj-chicano-batmans-musical-dna |title=Guest DJ: Chicano Batman's Musical DNA |date=7 June 2017 |work=NPR.org(Alt.Latino) |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
<ref name="WES_20150301">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2015/03/01/389945318/alt-latino-mixing-genres-with-chicano-batman-los-cenzontles |title=Alt.Latino: Mixing Genres With Chicano Batman, Los Cenzontles |date=1 March 2015 |work=NPR.org([[Weekend Edition]]) |accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref> <ref name="dailybulletin20150412">{{cite web|url=http://photos.dailybulletin.com/2015/04/photos-coachella-2015-chicano-batman-performs/ |title=Photos: Coachella 2015: Chicano Batman Performs |date=April 2015 |work=dailybulletin.com |accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref> }}

{{DEFAULTSORT:Chicano Batman}} [[Category:Musical groups established in 2008]] [[Category:Chicano]] [[Category:Mexican-American culture in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Latin music groups]] [[Category:Latin American music]] [[Category:Musical groups from Los Angeles]] [[Category:American soul musical groups]] [[Category:Psychedelic musical groups]] [[Category:Tropical musicians]]

The '''''Cinebox''''' was a coin-operated Italian 16mm [[Movie projector|film projector]] [[juke box]] type machine invented in 1959 that appeared in Europe to rival the French made [[Scopitone]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scopitonearchive.com/cinebox/index.html |title=Cinebox/Colorama/Cinejukebox |publisher=Scopitone Archive |date= |accessdate=2014-02-24}}</ref> that appeared in 1960.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michelebovi.it/?p=1965&lang=en |title=Michele BoviThe Spy-Story of Music Videos * Michele Bovi |publisher=Michelebovi.it |date= |accessdate=2014-02-24}}</ref> The Cinebox was manufactured in Rome by [[Ottico Meccanica Italiana]].
In 1963 it appeared in the USA<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lPYGAQAAIAAJ&q=cinebox&dq=cinebox&hl=en&ei=2QVnTbH3GoqKvQOMy-XjAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwADgK |title=Newsweek - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-24}}</ref> and was retitled '''''Colorama''''' in 1965. In 1961 Cinebox machines were placed on [[ocean liner]]s of the [[American Export Lines]] with Cineboxes showing cartoons and [[short subject]] comedies in on board nurseries whilst on board lounges showed musical and [[Travel documentary|travelogues]]. Each of the Cineboxes held five 40 minute films.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dCAEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA53&dq=%22the+three+stooges+go+around+the+world+on+eighty+cents%22&hl=en&ei=GQJnTbuwHIG3cKmY3Y0M&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CFQQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Billboard - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com.au |date=1961-09-25 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}</ref>
In the United States the Cinebox musical juke box provided three minutes of sound film for 25 cents with 40 titles available at a time on the machine.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=niADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA125&dq=cinebox&hl=en&ei=qwJnTYiHBIn0vQPG3OHjAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CEoQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=cinebox&f=false |title=Popular Science - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-24}}</ref>
In Canada, the Cinebox became the first e.commerce website (cinebox.net), founded by Loïc Berthout, to sell movies (DVD) online in 1998. It then proposed video games and reached an international scope. It was also selling through cinebox.com until 2010.
==References== {{Music video}} {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.scopitonearchive.com/cinebox/index.html Scopitone Archive] *[http://scopitonearchive.com/cinebox/a_to_m.html Cinebox Films]

{{film-tech-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} '''Coco Bulles''' is the International Festival of Cartoons and Comics of [[Abidjan]]. The aim is to give a panoramic view of the comic literature and graphics in Africa.
The festival contains art exhibitions, workshops, conferences and roundtables. The venue for the festival was the [[Culture Palace of Abidjan]], [[Côte d'Ivoire]].
==Past festivals== * 2001: The first Coco Bulles Festival is held 2-5 November 2001. : The motto of the festival was: "Long live the comic!". Some artists who participated the festival in 2001 were: Tristan Demers [http://www.lambiek.net/artists/d/demers_tristan.htm] ( the creator of 'Gargouille', one of the most popular characters in Quebec comics ) and [[Bernard Willem Holtrop]] ( one of the most controversial cartoonists in Europe) [http://lambiek.net/artists/w/willem.htm] * 2003: The second Coco Bulles Festival is held between 6-9 November 2003. : [[Switzerland]] was chosen as the guest of honour. The festival is organized by Olvis Dabley and cartoonists Zohoré Lassane [http://lambiek.net/artists/z/zed-l.htm], Illary Simplice [http://lambiek.net/artists/i/illary.htm] and Mendozza Y Caramba [http://www.lambiek.net/artists/m/mendozza-y-caramba.htm]. : Some artists who participated the festival in 2003 were: [[Jean-Claude Fournier]] who handled [[Spirou et Fantasio]] in the years 1969-1979, Claude Moliterni organizer of [[Angoulême International Comics Festival]], Christophe Bertschy [http://www.lambiek.net/artists/b/bertschy_christophe.htm] who created 'Nelson', a newspaper strip which appears in [[Le Matin (Switzerland)|Le Matin]] and in the german newspaper [[Bieler Tagblatt]]. * 2007: The third Coco Bulles Festival is held between 12-15 April 2007 : [[Belgium]] was chosen as the guest of honour. Some artists who participated the festival in 2007 were: Peter Kroll [http://www.cartooningforpeace.org/en/dessinateurs/kroll], Cécile Bertrand [https://web.archive.org/web/20110926114814/http://www.cartooningforpeace.org/en/dessinateurs/bertrand] and [[Daniel Henrotin]] [[Dany (comics)]]. : The theme was; "Comics and satirical, traces of time in search of balance". : Some artists who participated the festival in 2003 were Peter Kroll and Cécile Bertrand. * The fourth Coco Bulles was originally scheduled in November 2009 but was postponed indefinitely.
==External links== * A cartoon album about the Ivorian crisis with humor created by Patrick Chappatte in 2006 (in French) [http://www.globecartoon.com/bd/introBD2.html] * An article on Rezo-Ivory.net entitled "Coco Bulles 2007: Abidjan, Capitale de la BD Pendant 4 Jours" by Raymond Alex Loukou, 25/6/2007 (in French)[http://www.rezoivoire.net/Art/article/70/coco-bulles-2007-abidjan-capitale-de-la-bd-pendant-4-jours.html] * An article in AfriCultures.com entitled "LA BD Ivorienne se porte bien, Premier festival international du dessin de presse et de la bande dessinée en Côte d'Ivoire" by Sébastien Langevin (in French)[http://www.africultures.com/php/index.php?nav=article&no=133]
